fields.name: Geography
fields.description: Where are complaints coming from?

fields.name: Officer Characteristics
fields.description: Who has complaints?

fields.name: Complaint Categories
fields.description: What are the complaints about?

fields.name: Outcomes of Complaint Investigations
fields.description: What happened after the complaint was filed?

fields.name: Complaint Characteristic
fields.description: What information is featured?

fields.name: Complainant Demographic
fields.description: Who files complaints?

fields.name: Officer Demographic
fields.description: Who has complaints?

fields.name: Keywords
fields.description: Search the summary abstracts of complaints provided by IPRA for any words, like "taser" or "mediation”

fields.name: 90th Percentile for Complaints
fields.description: This search will find all officers who have more complaints per year than 90% of their fellow officers. This means that an officer who received nine complaints in two years as an officer might appear on this search, but an officer who has 20 complaints in 15 years might not.

fields.name: 99th Percentile for Complaints
fields.description: This search will find all officers who have more complaints per year than 99% of their fellow officers. This means that an officer who received nine complaints in two years as an officer might appear on this search, but an officer who has 20 complaints in 15 years might not.

fields.name: Active
fields.description: Active officers are presently serving in the CPD, per our most recent data.

fields.name: Administrative Termination
fields.description: This designation includes officers who have been fired by the Chicago Police. The process for firing an officer is time-consuming and involves a serious finding against an officer, input from the police superintendent, review by the city’s Police Board, and a grievance and appeal process. Officers sometimes resign after exhausting their appeals instead of being fired directly by the department. [Fact Check]

fields.name: Age 18-30
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: Age 31-40
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: Age 41-50
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: Age 51+
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: Arrest / Lockup Procedures
fields.description:
This category (04) includes complaints about misconduct during the process of arresting and processing a suspect. It also includes excessive detention, improper care of a detained person, and improper searches of a detained person.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Asian
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: Badge Number
fields.description: Each CPD officer has a badge number, which is typically displayed on their uniform. Badge numbers typically range between 1 and 20,000. An officer’s badge number may change multiple times over their career. Badge numbers are also reused when an officer leaves the force.

fields.name: Black
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: Bribery / Official Corruption
fields.description:
This category (06) includes complaints about official misconduct, including accepting or soliciting bribes, false testimony, and maintaining gang affiliations.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Census Tracts
fields.description: According to the Census Bureau, “census tracts are small, relatively permanent statistical subdivisions of a county or equivalent entity that are updated by local participants prior to each decennial census.” Each tract contains approximately 1,200 - 8,000 residents. In Chicago, census tracts generally fit within the city’s 77 community areas.

fields.name: Communities
fields.description: Chicago is divided into 77 community areas. These boundaries date back to the 1920s and have only been modified slightly in the intervening years. Community areas frequently contain multiple neighborhoods, but also often align fairly closely with existing community boundaries.

fields.name: Conduct Unbecoming (Off Duty)
fields.description:
This category (09) is made up of a wide range of non-physical misbehavior, including harassment, traffic violations, and off-duty altercations. 

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: CRID
fields.description: Each complaint is given a unique ID number (CRID). You can search for a specific case using the CRID here.

fields.name: Criminal Misconduct
fields.description:
This group of complaints (08) is comprised of categories where a police officer has allegedly committed a crime, not just an act of misconduct.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Disciplined 10-30 days
fields.description: This search will find cases where an officer was suspended between ten and thirty days as a result of the complaint.

fields.name: Disciplined 1-9 days
fields.description: This search will find cases where an officer was suspended between one and nine days as a result of the complaint.

fields.name: Disciplined 30+ days
fields.description: This search will find cases where an officer was suspended over thirty days as a result of the complaint. Suspensions over thirty days have to be reviewed by Chicago’s Police Board, which is appointed by the mayor. The Police Board sometimes overturns or reduces discipline.

fields.name: Domestic
fields.description:
This search will find use of force complaints that are marked as domestic-related. 

This search will only return complaints where one officer is named because due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a complaint accuses one officer of domestic violence and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers could have a complaint marked as “Domestic Altercation - Physical Abuse”

fields.name: Drug / Alcohol Abuse
fields.description:
This search will find complaints from two categories (02 and 15) that cover allegations of drug or alcohol abuse by officers. Types of complaints in this category include DUIs, failed drug tests, and drinking on duty.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Exonerated
fields.description: This designation means that investigators have determined that the officer did commit the actions detailed in the complaint, but also decided that those actions are within department policy. For example, investigators might rule that the actions described in an allegation of excessive force did take place, but that the force was appropriate.

fields.name: Female
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: has:address
fields.description: This will limit you search to cases where we have received address information for the incident, typically at the block level.

fields.name: has:documents
fields.description: This will limit your search to cases where we have obtained at least some of the official documents and made them available on this site.

fields.name: has:identified officer
fields.description: This will limit your search to cases where at least one officer has been identified. In some cases, the complainant is unable to name a specific officer.

fields.name: has:investigator
fields.description: This will limit your search to cases where we have received data about the investigator. Some cases are investigated by civilian investigators working for a police oversight agency (first called OPS, then IPRA, then COPA). Others are investigated by CPD personnel, usually either a supervisor or an officer assigned to the Bureau of Internal Affairs.

fields.name: has:summary
fields.description: This will limit your search to cases where we have obtained the summary of the complaint, which typically includes a description of the case and the investigation.

fields.name: Hispanic
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: Improper Search
fields.description:
This category (03) includes complaints about searches without a warrant, first amendment violations, planting drugs on a suspect, and unlawful detention.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Inactive
fields.description: Inactive officers have retired or left the force for other reasons.

fields.name: Male
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: No Action Taken
fields.description: This category means that the complaint has been sustained (meaning at least some of the allegations of misconduct were found to be true), but no types of discipline or reprimand were recommended as a result.

fields.name: No Affidavit
fields.description: Complaints made against a Chicago Police officer require a sworn affidavit to prompt an investigation. In a substantial number of complaints, the complainant is unwilling or unable to file a sworn affidavit, leading the complaint to be dropped. Chicago’s oversight agency, IPRA (now COPA), has the power to override the affidavit requirement and investigate a case, but has rarely used this power.

fields.name: No Discipline
fields.description: This search will return cases where investigators ruled that at least part of the complaint was sustained, but the officers involved did not receive any discipline. This includes categories such as “no action taken,” “violation noted,” “resigned,” “unknown,” and cases where officers are reinstated by either the Police Board or a court.

fields.name: Not Sustained
fields.description: A not sustained finding means that investigators have determined they do not have enough evidence to rule that the officer engaged in misconduct. It also means they did find enough evidence to rule that the allegations were either unfounded or that they did take place but did not violate department policy. Most cases that are investigated  by the CPD or its outside watchdog (first IPRA, now COPA) end in not sustained findings.

fields.name: Off-Duty
fields.description: Some complaints specifically refer to off-duty incidents. Other complaints may involve off-duty officers, but are not explicitly marked as such in the complaint category. Off-duty Chicago Police officers retain their police powers.

fields.name: Age 21-30
fields.description: CPD officers must be at least [21 years](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/CPD-2017-Police-Officer-FAQs-FINAL-111716-2.pdf) old. The CPD has a mandatory [retirement age](https://chicagocode.org/2-152-410/) of 63.

fields.name: Age 31-40
fields.description: CPD officers must be at least [21 years](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/CPD-2017-Police-Officer-FAQs-FINAL-111716-2.pdf) old. The CPD has a mandatory [retirement age](https://chicagocode.org/2-152-410/) of 63.

fields.name: Age 41-50
fields.description: CPD officers must be at least [21 years](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/CPD-2017-Police-Officer-FAQs-FINAL-111716-2.pdf) old. The CPD has a mandatory [retirement age](https://chicagocode.org/2-152-410/) of 63.

fields.name: Age 51+
fields.description: CPD officers must be at least [21 years](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/CPD-2017-Police-Officer-FAQs-FINAL-111716-2.pdf) old. The CPD has a mandatory [retirement age](https://chicagocode.org/2-152-410/) of 63.

fields.name: Asian
fields.description: As of 2010 (when the CPD last published its [annual report](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2010-Annual-Report.pdf)), 53% of CPD officers were white, 25% were black, 19% were Hispanic, and 3% were of other races. Those numbers had changed over the preceding decade, with the number of white officers decreasing slightly while the number of Hispanic officers has grown slightly.

fields.name: Black
fields.description: As of 2010 (when the CPD last published its [annual report](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2010-Annual-Report.pdf)), 53% of CPD officers were white, 25% were black, 19% were Hispanic, and 3% were of other races. Those numbers had changed over the preceding decade, with the number of white officers decreasing slightly while the number of Hispanic officers has grown slightly.

fields.name: Female
fields.description: As of 2010 (when the CPD last published its [annual report](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2010-Annual-Report.pdf)), 76% of CPD officers were male and 24% were female.

fields.name: Hispanic
fields.description: As of 2010 (when the CPD last published its [annual report](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2010-Annual-Report.pdf)), 53% of CPD officers were white, 25% were black, 19% were Hispanic, and 3% were of other races. Those numbers had changed over the preceding decade, with the number of white officers decreasing slightly while the number of Hispanic officers has grown slightly.

fields.name: Male
fields.description: As of 2010 (when the CPD last published its [annual report](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2010-Annual-Report.pdf)), 76% of CPD officers were male and 24% were female.

fields.name: Name
fields.description: Type the name of an officer into the search bar

fields.name: Others
fields.description: As of 2010 (when the CPD last published its [annual report](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2010-Annual-Report.pdf)), 53% of CPD officers were white, 25% were black, 19% were Hispanic, and 3% were of other races. Those numbers had changed over the preceding decade, with the number of white officers decreasing slightly while the number of Hispanic officers has grown slightly.

fields.name: Rank
fields.description: The Chicago Police Department is organized by rank. Police Officers make up the bulk of the department, patrolling neighborhoods and serving on specialized teams. Detectives are at type of specialized police officer who conduct investigations. Sergeants are lower-level supervisors who oversee roughly a dozen officers (though this varies widely) and sometimes command small teams. Lieutenants are mid-level supervisors who run teams and may be responsible for supervising shifts for an entire police district. A Commander runs each of Chicago’s 22 police districts and sometimes hold other leadership roles. Each district Commander is typically supported by a single Captain. Above commanders are a range of high-level officials, including Deputy Chiefs and Chiefs. These officials may oversee multiple police districts or an entire bureau (like investigations or patrol). The CPD is led by the Superintendent.

fields.name: Unit
fields.description: The Chicago Police Department is organized into a number of units, with substantial variation in size and role. For example, Unit 003 is the Third District and includes hundreds of officers who patrol Woodlawn and nearby neighborhoods. Other units are much smaller and might include record-keeping divisions, SWAT teams, or human resources.

fields.name: White
fields.description: As of 2010 (when the CPD last published its [annual report](https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2010-Annual-Report.pdf)), 53% of CPD officers were white, 25% were black, 19% were Hispanic, and 3% were of other races. Those numbers had changed over the preceding decade, with the number of white officers decreasing slightly while the number of Hispanic officers has grown slightly.

fields.name: Open
fields.description: Open cases are still being actively investigated at the time this data was last updated. Cases frequently take years to wind through the investigation process.

fields.name: Operation / Personnel Violations
fields.description:
This category (10) includes on-duty administrative violations like leaving or failing to show up for work, having an unauthorized second job, or poor handling of a request for police assistance. These complaints are more likely to be initiated by other police officers.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Others
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: Penalty Not Served
fields.description: This category includes officers who have not served discipline, but may be required to do so in the future. For example, investigators might recommend an officer be suspended, but that suspension cannot be served because the officer is on indefinite medical leave.

fields.name: Police Beat
fields.description: Police beats are the smallest area patrolled by officers, usually made up of a few dozen blocks. Many officers are assigned to specific beats and exclusively patrol these areas.

fields.name: Police District
fields.description: Chicago is divided into 22 police districts. Each district has several hundred officers, though there is substantial variation in the size and population of each district. Most Chicago police officers, including the vast majority of patrol officers, are assigned to a specific police district. Some types of officers, such as SWAT officers, detectives, and narcotics officers support several districts or work citywide.

fields.name: Reinstated by Police Board
fields.description: Chicago’s Police Board, a body appointed by the mayor, reviews major disciplinary rulings against officers. It must approve department moves to fire officers or suspend them for more than 30 days. The Board has historically overturned discipline in a substantial number of cases, reinstating officers who were to be fired, shortening suspensions, or converting a firing recommendation into a suspension.

fields.name: Reprimand
fields.description: A minor type of discipline in which an officer is issued a formal reprimand for misconduct. This is the most serious type of discipline short of a suspension.

fields.name: Resigned
fields.description: This designation signals that an officer resigned before the full disciplinary process had run its course. Some officers may have merely retire with a case unsettled, but Chicago’s very slow process for firing officers also means that many officers accused of serious misconduct exhaust their appeals and then resign when it is clear they will be fired.

fields.name: Public Schools
fields.description: This search will show any complaints located within 1,000 meters of a Chicago Public School. These complaints are not necessarily related to the school. Many CPS schools do have dedicated police officers supplied by the CPD.

fields.name: Supervisory Responsibilities
fields.description:
This category (12) consists of complaints that specifically apply to CPD supervisors. This includes failing to properly supervise subordinates, failure to conduct an adequate investigation, and failure to intake a civilian complaint.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Sustained
fields.description: A complaint ending in a sustained finding means that investigators determined that at least some of the alleged misconduct did take place. A sustained finding can result in discipline for an officer (range from a reprimand to a suspension to a firing), but not all sustained cases result in discipline. Additionally, many cases have multiple allegations of misconduct (i.e. an officer is accused of using excessive force and also of not filing the correct paperwork after using that force). If any of those allegations are found to be true, then the whole case is marked as “sustained” in the CPD’s data systems.

fields.name: Traffic
fields.description:
This category (07) includes complaints related to traffic stops and citations, excluding alleged bribes or uses of force that take place during traffic stops.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Unfounded
fields.description: This finding occurs when the investigator determines that the allegations against an officer did not occur. Like “exonerated” or “not sustained” complaints, unfounded complaints do not result in discipline. Unlike these other categories, this finding means that investigators determined that the original allegations against the officer contained falsehoods.

fields.name: Unsustained
fields.description: This category includes all cases where investigators did not rule against an officer. This includes cases marked as “not sustained”, “unfounded”, “no affidavit”, “exonerated”, “unknown” and “no cooperation”

fields.name: Use Of Force
fields.description:
This category (05) includes a wide range of complaints, mostly involving different types of police use of force.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Verbal Abuse
fields.description:
This category (01) includes complaints about profanity, racial slurs, or other forms of biased language. As of 2018, this type of complaint is typically investigated by COPA, Chicago’s civilian police watchdog.

Due to the limitations of the CPD’s data systems, each complaint is only marked with one allegation type. This means that if a single complaint accuses one officer of excessive force and two other officers of foul language, then all three officers will have a complaint marked as “excessive force.”

fields.name: Violation Noted
fields.description: This is a minor type of discipline in which an officer’s misconduct is officially noted on their record, but no other discipline is handed out.

fields.name: Ward
fields.description: Chicago is divided into 50 wards, each of which elects an alderman to City Council. Chicago’s wards often overlap the city’s neighborhoods, but are frequently shaped by political considerations as well.

fields.name: White
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: X
fields.description:
The complainant is the person who filed the complaint and is not necessarily the victim of the alleged police misconduct.

Not all complaints have demographic information about the person who filed the complaint, especially those filed prior to September 2007. Some complaints are also jointly filed by multiple individuals.

fields.name: Zip Codes
fields.description: Used by the US Postal Service, zip codes often run through multiple neighborhoods. While less precise than police districts or community areas, they can still be used to search a particular area.
